sect1.title: Rectangle Selection Tool

caption.para: The toolbox highlighting the Rectangle Selection tool

sect1.para: The Rectangle Selection tool is designed to select rectangular regions from images or layers such that you can work on a specific area of an image or layer.

listitem.para: The available tool options for Rectangle Select can be accessed by double clicking the Rectangle Select tool icon.
The replace mode will cause any existing selection to be destroyed or replaced when the new selection is created.
The add mode will cause the new selection to be added to any existing selection regions. SHIFT.
The subtract mode will remove the new selection area from any existing selection regions. CTRL.
The intersection mode will make a new selection are from the area where the existing selection region and the new selection region overlap. CTRL+SHIFT.
The Radius slider adjusts the amount of feathering in pixels for the next selection that is created. For further information regarding feathering, see the glossary entry FIXME.
The Auto Shrink Selection checkbox will make the next selection automatically shrink to the nearest rectangular shape available on the image layer if one can be detected.

If Sample Merged is also enabled, then the Auto Shrink will utilize the pixel information from all the layers of the image. For further information regarding Sample Merge, see the glossary entry FIXME.
Enabling Fixed Size will allow you to manually specify a size for the selection using the Width, Height, and Unit controls.
The r key will change the active tool to Rectangle Select.

Holding Ctrl while creating a rectangular selection can do up to two things. Firstly, the selection will be created using the pixel you started the selection on as a center. Normally, the selection is created using that pixel as a corner. Secondly, Ctrl will place the selection into subtraction mode (see above). If you only require one of the actions to take place, you can release the Ctrl key prior to releasing the mouse button. Doing so will leave the selection in subtraction mode, but without the center point constraint.
Holding Alt will allow movement of the current selection.

Holding Shift while creating a selection will perform up to two different things. The first is constraint such that the height and width of the selection will remain equal (a square). Secondly, this key modifier will ensure that the selection mode is changed to addition (see above). If you require only one of these actions to take place, you can release the Shift key prior to releasing the mouse button. Doing so will leave the selection in addition mode, but without the height and width constraints.

Using
Ctrl Shift
can do a variety of things. Both keys alone will do up to two things. Firstly the selection mode will be switched to intersection (or union). Secondly, the selection will have both the center point constraint discussed above and the height and width constraints (also discussed above). It is an exercise for the reader to play with the various combinations available when performing rectangular selections while holding
Ctrl Shift
and releasing either both or either prior to releasing the mouse button.

warning.para: When moving a selection beyond the boundaries of the image canvas, the selection will be cropped to the image area. Selections can only exist on the visible canvas. Selection movements and changes are however kept in the undo buffer should you have the need of repairing an error.
